<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A novel supramolecular complex containing one-dimensional channels of formula [Cd(2,2′<ce:bold>-</ce:bold>bipy)(Phmal)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·1.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (Phmal=phenylmalonate, 2,2′‐bipy=2,2′-bipyridine) has been synthesized and characterized by FT-IR spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis (TG), UV–vis spectra. X-ray crystallographic studies of the complex reveal that the cadmium atom exhibits a distorted octahedral geometry being coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of 2,2′‐bipy, three oxygen atoms from the phenylmalonate ligand and one water. The supramolecular network is constructed from one dimensional chain which was further linked by O–H⋯O hydrogen bonds and intermolecular π–π stacking interactions. The complex represents the first three‐dimensional supramolecuar network constructed from the mixed phmal and 2,2′‐bipy ligand.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel supramolecular complex containing one-dimensional channels of formula [Cd(2,2'-bipy)(Phmal)(H2O)]⋅1.5H2O (Phmal=phenylmalonate, 2,2'-bipy=2,2'-bipyridine) has been synthesized and characterized by FT-IR spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis (TG), UV-vis spectra. X-ray crystallographic studies of the complex reveal that the cadmium atom exhibits a distorted octahedral geometry being coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of 2,2'-bipy, three oxygen atoms from the phenylmalonate ligand and one water. The supramolecular network is constructed from one dimensional chain which was further linked by O-H⋯O hydrogen bonds and intermolecular π-π stacking interactions. The complex represents the first three-dimensional supramolecuar network constructed from the mixed phmal and 2,2'-bipy ligand.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Recently, the design and synthesis of supramolecular networks with channel structures that provide new shapes, sizes and chemical environments has attracted more and more attention . This is not only due to their complicated structural diversity, but also due to their potential applications in ion exchange, molecular adsorption and heterogenous catalysis . Several approaches directed toward the design of open networks have successfully produced many valuable frameworks with variable size cavities or channels . Apart from the covalent interactions, the contacts such as the hydrogen-bonding and aromatic π–π stacking interactions have also been used to design and synthesize porous complexes . However, most pure organic and coordination polymers do not possess porous structure because of the formation of an interpenetration structure. Thus, the design and synthesis of porous metal-organic frameworks from molecular building blocks is one of the most challenging issues for chemists. A new method for synthesizing stable pillared-layer structures using coordination networks has been developed and succeeded in synthesizing a series of porous materials with novel properties . The control of the network parameters through a careful selection of the metal ion and organic ligands offers new possibilities for developing new functional materials . Use of flexible ligands should offer a greater degree of structural diversity and often be regarded as an effective strategy for construction of porous or other functional materials. Recently, we have started a systematic study on metal(II) coordination with phenylmalonate ligand (dianion of phenylmalonic acid, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Phmal). One of the goals of this project is to analyze the influence that factors such as the rigidity and the possibility of specific attractive interactions between phenyl rings can exert on the structure and functional properties of phenylmalonate—containing metal(II) complexes. Phmal is a suitable candidate for assembling such complexes due to its two interesting structural features. In the first place, it can adopt several kinds of coordination modes in metal complexes, which may provide abundant structural motifs . Secondly, it can act as hydrogen-bond acceptors and provide the pyridyl ring which may cause the aromatic π–π stacking interactions. To our best knowledge, the coordination polymers with phmal ligand have not been extensively studied . Furthermore, the introduction of 2,2′-bipy ligand may induce new structural evolution. The 2, 2′-bipy ligand is important in maintaining the desired low dimensional coordination polymer and may provide potential supramolecular recognition sites for π–π aromatic stacking interactions. So, we assumed that phmal ligand could be useful in the formation of supramolecular frameworks with some important features in the presence of 2,2′-bipy chelate ligand. In the present paper, we report a novel porous coordination polymer [Cd(2,2′-bipy)(Phmal)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·1.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. The complex exhibits a three-dimensional supramolecular framework with one-dimensional channels, which is constructed from infinite one dimensional chains via O–H⋯O hydrogen bonding and aromatic π–π stacking interactions. To the best of our knowledge, the title complex is the first three-dimensional supramolecular network containing one‐dimensional channels constructed from the mixed phmal and 2,2′-bipy ligand.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently, the design and synthesis of supramolecular networks with channel structures that provide new shapes, sizes and chemical environments has attracted more and more attention . This is not only due to their complicated structural diversity, but also due to their potential applications in ion exchange, molecular adsorption and heterogenous catalysis . Several approaches directed toward the design of open networks have successfully produced many valuable frameworks with variable size cavities or channels . Apart from the covalent interactions, the contacts such as the hydrogen-bonding and aromatic π-π stacking interactions have also been used to design and synthesize porous complexes . However, most pure organic and coordination polymers do not possess porous structure because of the formation of an interpenetration structure. Thus, the design and synthesis of porous metal-organic frameworks from molecular building blocks is one of the most challenging issues for chemists. A new method for synthesizing stable pillared-layer structures using coordination networks has been developed and succeeded in synthesizing a series of porous materials with novel properties . The control of the network parameters through a careful selection of the metal ion and organic ligands offers new possibilities for developing new functional materials . Use of flexible ligands should offer a greater degree of structural diversity and often be regarded as an effective strategy for construction of porous or other functional materials. Recently, we have started a systematic study on metal(II) coordination with phenylmalonate ligand (dianion of phenylmalonic acid, H2Phmal). One of the goals of this project is to analyze the influence that factors such as the rigidity and the possibility of specific attractive interactions between phenyl rings can exert on the structure and functional properties of phenylmalonate-containing metal(II) complexes. Phmal is a suitable candidate for assembling such complexes due to its two interesting structural features. In the first place, it can adopt several kinds of coordination modes in metal complexes, which may provide abundant structural motifs . Secondly, it can act as hydrogen-bond acceptors and provide the pyridyl ring which may cause the aromatic π-π stacking interactions. To our best knowledge, the coordination polymers with phmal ligand have not been extensively studied . Furthermore, the introduction of 2,2'-bipy ligand may induce new structural evolution. The 2, 2'-bipy ligand is important in maintaining the desired low dimensional coordination polymer and may provide potential supramolecular recognition sites for π-π aromatic stacking interactions. So, we assumed that phmal ligand could be useful in the formation of supramolecular frameworks with some important features in the presence of 2,2'-bipy chelate ligand. In the present paper, we report a novel porous coordination polymer [Cd(2,2'-bipy)(Phmal)(H2O)]⋅1.5H2O. The complex exhibits a three-dimensional supramolecular framework with one-dimensional channels, which is constructed from infinite one dimensional chains via O-H⋯O hydrogen bonding and aromatic π-π stacking interactions. To the best of our knowledge, the title complex is the first three-dimensional supramolecular network containing one-dimensional channels constructed from the mixed phmal and 2,2'-bipy ligand.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials and characterization</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All reagents were used as purchased. Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were carried out on a 240 C Elemental analyzer. Infrared spectrum (400–4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) was recorded from KBr pellet in Magna 750 FT-IR spectrophotometer and UV–vis spectra on a Shimadzu UV-3100 spectrophotometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was taken on NETZSCH STA 409 PG/PC instrument.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and characterization

All reagents were used as purchased. Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were carried out on a 240 C Elemental analyzer. Infrared spectrum (400-4000cm-1) was recorded from KBr pellet in Magna 750 FT-IR spectrophotometer and UV-vis spectra on a Shimadzu UV-3100 spectrophotometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was taken on NETZSCH STA 409 PG/PC instrument.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">2,2′-Bipyridine (0.0866<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g. 0.555<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was dissolved in methanol (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) and then an aqueous solution of Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.1712<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g. 0.555<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in water (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) was added whilst stirring. To this solution a mixture of phenylmalonic acid (0.100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.555<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and NaOH (0.0333<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.832<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in water (20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) was added and refluxed for 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min and then filtered. The filtrate was kept at ambient temperature for several days and colorless crystals were formed. They were filtered and washed thoroughly with methanol and dried in vacuum (yield: 39.0% based on phenylmalonic acid). Anal. Calcd for C<ce:inf loc="post">19</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">19</ce:inf>CdN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6.5</ce:inf>: C, 46.40; H, 3.89; N, 5.70. Found: C, 46.42; H, 4.10; N, 5.32.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

2,2'-Bipyridine (0.0866g. 0.555mmol) was dissolved in methanol (10ml) and then an aqueous solution of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.1712g. 0.555mmol) in water (10ml) was added whilst stirring. To this solution a mixture of phenylmalonic acid (0.100g, 0.555mmol) and NaOH (0.0333g, 0.832mmol) in water (20ml) was added and refluxed for 10min and then filtered. The filtrate was kept at ambient temperature for several days and colorless crystals were formed. They were filtered and washed thoroughly with methanol and dried in vacuum (yield: 39.0% based on phenylmalonic acid). Anal. Calcd for C19H19CdN2O6.5: C, 46.40; H, 3.89; N, 5.70. Found: C, 46.42; H, 4.10; N, 5.32.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>X-ray crystallography study</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A colorless crystal having approximated dimensions 0.78×0.24×0.18<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm was used for data collection. Diffraction data were collected at 293(2) K with a Siemens SMART CCD diffractormeter using graphite-monochromated (Mo-Kα) radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), <ce:italic>ψ</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>ω</ce:italic> scans mode. elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography study

A colorless crystal having approximated dimensions 0.78×0.24×0.18mm was used for data collection. Diffraction data were collected at 293(2) K with a Siemens SMART CCD diffractormeter using graphite-monochromated (Mo-Kα) radiation (λ=0.71073Å), ψ and ω scans mode. The cell constants were determined from the full-matrix least-squares fit of 4527 reflections with θ in the range 1.70° and 25.06°. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by a full-matrix least-squares on F 2 method. Intensity data were corrected for Lorenz and polarization effects and an empirical absorption correction was performed. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were added geometrically and allowed to ride on their respective parent atoms. The contribution of these hydrogen atoms was included in the structure factor calculations. All calculations were carried out on a PC 586 computer using SHELXL-97 program . Details of crystal data, collection and refinement are listed in  .

<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Structural description</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Determination of the structure of [Cd(2,2′-bipy)(Phmal)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·1.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O by X-ray crystallography reveals that the complex consists of one Cd atom, one phmal ligand, one 2,2′-bipy ligand, one water and 1.5 crystallization water molecules in each independent crystallographic unit (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>). The Cd atom, which is in a distorted octahedral environment, is coordinated by two N atoms from a chelating 2,2′-bipy ligand [Cd(1)–N(1)=2.341(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Cd(1)–N(2)=2.320(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å], two carboxylic oxygens from the phmal ligand [Cd(1)–O(1)=2.312(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Cd(1)–O(2)=2.435(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å], one carboxylic oxygen atom from the other phmal ligand [Cd(1)–O(3)#1=2.247(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, #1: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>−1, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>] and one water. Selected bond distances and angles are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>. The angles subtended the Cd atom ranges from 54.08(11) to 145.68(19)°. Two carboxylic groups in the phmal ligand exhibit different coordination modes. One is in a bidentate mode, while the other exhibits the monodentate mode. The flexible phmal ligands interconnect the Cd atoms to form one-dimensional zigzag chains with an adjacent Cd⋯Cd distance of 7.620<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The 2,2′ -bipy ligand is practically planar [the dihedral angle between the mean pyridyl planes is 1.70°, which is larger than that in the mononuclear copper (II) complex [Cu(2,2′-bipy)(Phmal)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1.11°)] . Its bond lengths and angles are almost the same as those reported for free 2,2′-bipy . The Phmal group in the title complex exhibits the same boat conformation as in the reported complex {[Cu(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>][Cu(Phmal)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]}<ce:inf loc="post">

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Structural description

Determination of the structure of [Cd(2,2'-bipy)(Phmal)(H2O)]⋅1.5H2O by X-ray crystallography reveals that the complex consists of one Cd atom, one phmal ligand, one 2,2'-bipy ligand, one water and 1.5 crystallization water molecules in each independent crystallographic unit ( ). The Cd atom, which is in a distorted octahedral environment, is coordinated by two N atoms from a chelating 2,2'-bipy ligand [Cd(1)-N(1)=2.341(3)Å, Cd(1)-N(2)=2.320(4)Å], two carboxylic oxygens from the phmal ligand [Cd(1)-O(1)=2.312(3)Å, Cd(1)-O(2)=2.435(4)Å], one carboxylic oxygen atom from the other phmal ligand [Cd(1)-O(3)#1=2.247(3)Å, #1: x-1, y, z] and one water. Selected bond distances and angles are listed in  . The angles subtended the Cd atom ranges from 54.08(11) to 145.68(19)°. Two carboxylic groups in the phmal ligand exhibit different coordination modes. One is in a bidentate mode, while the other exhibits the monodentate mode. The flexible phmal ligands interconnect the Cd atoms to form one-dimensional zigzag chains with an adjacent Cd⋯Cd distance of 7.620Å. The 2,2' -bipy ligand is practically planar [the dihedral angle between the mean pyridyl planes is 1.70°, which is larger than that in the mononuclear copper (II) complex [Cu(2,2'-bipy)(Phmal)(H2O)]⋅2H2O (1.11°)] . Its bond lengths and angles are almost the same as those reported for free 2,2'-bipy . The Phmal group in the title complex exhibits the same boat conformation as in the reported complex {[Cu(H2O)3][Cu(Phmal)2]} n  .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">It is interesting that the 2,2′-bipy ligands are arranged uniquely at one side of the chain, while the pyridyl ring in the phmal ligand is arranged uniquely at the other side of the chain as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>. The adjacent chains recognize each other through offset π–π stacking interactions of the 2,2′-bipy ligand and pyridyl ring in phmal ligand (the separations of adjacent aromatic rings are 3.816<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for pyridyl ring and 3.826<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for 2,2′-bipy rings, respectively). The one-dimensional chains were further linked through hydrogen bonding [O(4)⋯O(5)(−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) 2.623(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; O(2)⋯O(5)(<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, −1+<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) 2.858(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; O(1)⋯O(6)(1−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) 2.799(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; O(7)⋯O(6) 2.785(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; O(7)#3⋯O(6)(1+<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1+<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) 2.889(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å #3: −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>]. Hydrogen bonding interactions are very important in the preparation of supramolecular architectures . Undoubtedly, both the π–π stacking interactions and the hydrogen bonding play important roles in the stabilization of the title coordination compound. Thus, a novel three-dimensional supramolecular network featuring one-dimensional channels with the dimensions 11.797×12.061<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å was formed (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example that contains one dimensional channels among the reported complexes .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is interesting that the 2,2'-bipy ligands are arranged uniquely at one side of the chain, while the pyridyl ring in the phmal ligand is arranged uniquely at the other side of the chain as shown in  . The adjacent chains recognize each other through offset π-π stacking interactions of the 2,2'-bipy ligand and pyridyl ring in phmal ligand (the separations of adjacent aromatic rings are 3.816Å for pyridyl ring and 3.826Å for 2,2'-bipy rings, respectively). The one-dimensional chains were further linked through hydrogen bonding [O(4)⋯O(5)(-x, 1-y, z) 2.623(2)Å; O(2)⋯O(5)(x, -1+y, z) 2.858(2)Å; O(1)⋯O(6)(1-x, 1-y, z) 2.799(2)Å; O(7)⋯O(6) 2.785(3)Å; O(7)#3⋯O(6)(1+x, y, 1+z) 2.889(2)Å #3: -x, 1-y, 1-z]. Hydrogen bonding interactions are very important in the preparation of supramolecular architectures . Undoubtedly, both the π-π stacking interactions and the hydrogen bonding play important roles in the stabilization of the title coordination compound. Thus, a novel three-dimensional supramolecular network featuring one-dimensional channels with the dimensions 11.797×12.061Å was formed ( ). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example that contains one dimensional channels among the reported complexes .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>UV–vis spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In the UV–vis spectra of the present complex in solid state, two absorption bands centered at 299 and 252<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm were observed. The band at 299<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm may be due to the metal to ligand charge transfer transition (MLCT). The band at 252<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm may arise from the π–π transitions of the ligands. While in the UV–vis spectra in methanol, an absorption band at 306<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm was observed, which may arise from the metal-to-ligand charge transfer transition (MLCT). The bands of 238, 285 and 294<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm can be attributed to the π–π transitions of the ligands. This indicates that the structure of the title complex in solid state is quite different from that in methanol solution.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
UV-vis spectra

In the UV-vis spectra of the present complex in solid state, two absorption bands centered at 299 and 252nm were observed. The band at 299nm may be due to the metal to ligand charge transfer transition (MLCT). The band at 252nm may arise from the π-π transitions of the ligands. While in the UV-vis spectra in methanol, an absorption band at 306nm was observed, which may arise from the metal-to-ligand charge transfer transition (MLCT). The bands of 238, 285 and 294nm can be attributed to the π-π transitions of the ligands. This indicates that the structure of the title complex in solid state is quite different from that in methanol solution.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>FT-IR spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The FT-IR spectra of the title compound show characteristic bands of carboxylate groups at 1591 and 1570<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for asymmetric stretching and that at 1441<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for symmetric stretching, respectively . The broad band around 3408<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> may be assigned to the water molecules with hydrogen bonds. The band at 1408<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> may be attributed to the ring stretching vibrations of the coordinated 2,2′-bipyridine, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
FT-IR spectra

The FT-IR spectra of the title compound show characteristic bands of carboxylate groups at 1591 and 1570cm-1 for asymmetric stretching and that at 1441cm-1 for symmetric stretching, respectively . The broad band around 3408cm-1 may be assigned to the water molecules with hydrogen bonds. The band at 1408cm-1 may be attributed to the ring stretching vibrations of the coordinated 2,2'-bipyridine, respectively.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Thermogravimetric analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The thermal behavior of the title coordination compound has been deduced from the TG curve in N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. The weight loss of 41.11% in the temperature range 60–318<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be atributed to the removal of 2.5 water and one 2,2′- bipy per formula unit (calcd 40.92%). The total weight loss of 74.01% in the temperature range 60–780<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which is in agreement with the weight loss calculated for the loss of both organic moieties and water molecules leading to the formation of CdO as final residuals above 780<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (calcd 73.89%).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric analysis

The thermal behavior of the title coordination compound has been deduced from the TG curve in N2. The weight loss of 41.11% in the temperature range 60-318°C can be atributed to the removal of 2.5 water and one 2,2'- bipy per formula unit (calcd 40.92%). The total weight loss of 74.01% in the temperature range 60-780°C, which is in agreement with the weight loss calculated for the loss of both organic moieties and water molecules leading to the formation of CdO as final residuals above 780°C (calcd 73.89%).

cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

2,2'-Bipyridine (0.0866g. 0.555mmol) was dissolved in methanol (10ml) and then an aqueous solution of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.1712g. 0.555mmol) in water (10ml) was added whilst stirring. To this solution a mixture of phenylmalonic acid (0.100g, 0.555mmol) and NaOH (0.0333g, 0.832mmol) in water (20ml) was added and refluxed for 10min and then filtered. The filtrate was kept at ambient temperature for several days and colorless crystals were formed. They were filtered and washed thoroughly with methanol and dried in vacuum (yield: 39.0% based on phenylmalonic acid). Anal. Calcd for C19H19CdN2O6.5: C, 46.40; H, 3.89; N, 5.70. Found: C, 46.42; H, 4.10; N, 5.32.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Structural description

Determination of the structure of [Cd(2,2'-bipy)(Phmal)(H2O)]⋅1.5H2O by X-ray crystallography reveals that the complex consists of one Cd atom, one phmal ligand, one 2,2'-bipy ligand, one water and 1.5 crystallization water molecules in each independent crystallographic unit ( ). The Cd atom, which is in a distorted octahedral environment, is coordinated by two N atoms from a chelating 2,2'-bipy ligand [Cd(1)-N(1)=2.341(3)Å, Cd(1)-N(2)=2.320(4)Å], two carboxylic oxygens from the phmal ligand [Cd(1)-O(1)=2.312(3)Å, Cd(1)-O(2)=2.435(4)Å], one carboxylic oxygen atom from the other phmal ligand [Cd(1)-O(3)#1=2.247(3)Å, #1: x-1, y, z] and one water. Selected bond distances and angles are listed in  . The angles subtended the Cd atom ranges from 54.08(11) to 145.68(19)°. Two carboxylic groups in the phmal ligand exhibit different coordination modes. One is in a bidentate mode, while the other exhibits the monodentate mode. The flexible phmal ligands interconnect the Cd atoms to form one-dimensional zigzag chains with an adjacent Cd⋯Cd distance of 7.620Å. The 2,2' -bipy ligand is practically planar [the dihedral angle between the mean pyridyl planes is 1.70°, which is larger than that in the mononuclear copper (II) complex [Cu(2,2'-bipy)(Phmal)(H2O)]⋅2H2O (1.11°)] . Its bond lengths and angles are almost the same as those reported for free 2,2'-bipy . The Phmal group in the title complex exhibits the same boat conformation as in the reported complex {[Cu(H2O)3][Cu(Phmal)2]} n  .

UV-vis spectra

In the UV-vis spectra of the present complex in solid state, two absorption bands centered at 299 and 252nm were observed. The band at 299nm may be due to the metal to ligand charge transfer transition (MLCT). The band at 252nm may arise from the π-π transitions of the ligands. While in the UV-vis spectra in methanol, an absorption band at 306nm was observed, which may arise from the metal-to-ligand charge transfer transition (MLCT). The bands of 238, 285 and 294nm can be attributed to the π-π transitions of the ligands. This indicates that the structure of the title complex in solid state is quite different from that in methanol solution.

Thermogravimetric analysis

The thermal behavior of the title coordination compound has been deduced from the TG curve in N2. The weight loss of 41.11% in the temperature range 60-318°C can be atributed to the removal of 2.5 water and one 2,2'- bipy per formula unit (calcd 40.92%). The total weight loss of 74.01% in the temperature range 60-780°C, which is in agreement with the weight loss calculated for the loss of both organic moieties and water molecules leading to the formation of CdO as final residuals above 780°C (calcd 73.89%).
